The group's representative, Appoline, is the one in the photo with her hand raised. She is 45 years old and married to a man named Jean. She has attended elementary school and is the mother of four children, all in school and in her care. Appoline lives together with  her husband and children, and she jointly ensures, along with her husband, that the different household expenses are covered.

To meet different family needs, Appoline has been selling grains (rice, corn) and canned foods for about twenty years in her district. This business enables her to meet her needs, as well as those of her children, without much problem. Christine gets her supplies from a market in Benin. 

Seeking to satisfy her customers and to grow her sales and revenues, Appoline, along with the other members of the group LA PAIX 1, is requesting a third loan from ALIDé. The first two loans were indeed paid back.

loans.use: to buy grains (rice, corn) and canned foods

loans.name: Rodolfo

texts.es:
Don Rodolfo, tiene 53 años de edad, es casado, tiene 5 hijos, vive en una aldea rural del municipio de Nueva Frontera junto a sus esposa e hijos.
Toda su vida se ha dedicado a la agricultura, hace 20 años que cultiva sus propios cultivos de café, y granos básicos como maíz y frijoles. Esta producción la vende en el mercado local pues es su única fuente de ingresos para el sostenimiento de su familia. Esta solicitando ya un segundo préstamo a ODEF, y también lo invertirá en darle asistencia y mantenimiento a sus cultivos, comprara fertilizantes y cubrirá gastos de limpieza y siembra de café y granos básicos. Esta inversión le ayuda a sacar mas producción y de calidad. Su meta es ampliar la producción y darle una buena asistencia para sacar buenas cosechas que le ayuden a obtener más ganancias para poder vivir mejor con su familia.
texts.en:
Rodolfo, age 53, is married and has five children.  He lives with his wife and children in a rural village in the Nueva Frontera municipality.

He has devoted himself to agriculture his whole life.  He has been cultivating his own coffee crops and basic grains, like corn and beans, for 20 years.  He sells this production at the local market.  It is his only source of income to support his family.

He is now requesting his second loan with ODEF.  He will use it to provide care and maintenance to his crops.  He will buy fertilizers and cover the costs of clearing the land and planting coffee and basic grains.  

This investment will help him get greater production and quality production.  His goal is to increase production and to give good care to the crops in order to get good harvests.  These will help him get more income to be able to live better with his family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and cover the costs of clearing the land and planting coffee, corn, and beans.

loans.name: Sibeso

texts.en:
In the heart of the copperbelt province of Zambia lies the city of Kitwe. It is the second biggest town in Zambia. This is where Sibeso owns her mobile money transfer business. She is 20 years old and lives alone. 

Sibeso comes from a family of four. She has a high school level of education. Once her business starts to make more profit, she plans to take a banking and finance course because she believes this set of skills will add value to her business. Sibeso has been running her business for three months now. She loves her business because it is able to provide money to customers who urgently need the money and it puts a smile on their faces.

When asked what challenges she faces in her business, Sibeso says that transportation of cash to and from the bank is very difficult because her location is not very secure.  She says once she gets the Kiva loan, she will not have to move cash with her because she will have enough working capital and it will be much easier to go about her day-to-day business.

The Kiva loan will help Sibeso to hire two people to help her in her shop. She says it will also help her to add to her working capital so that she does not have to constantly carry cash to and from the bank.

Sibeso asks Kiva lenders to help her increase her working capital, serve more customers, and earn more profits. She plans to use her profits to study banking and finance in a part-time course.

loans.use: To employ two people in her shop and add to her working capital.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is married and lives with her life companion and their four children. Her work is selling cooked food. She has worked in this business for a number of years since it has given her very good results, and at the same time it helped her acquire great experience in preparing food. 

She is very well known in the village where she sells because, as a walking vendor, she sells the most delicious food. She already has an extensive clientele because the food that she makes is of the highest quality, with an exquisite flavor and at affordable prices. In addition, her service is very rapid. 

Elizabeth is a woman with many goals to achieve. She works day after day to have a prosperous future. Since she has increased her clientele, she wants to increase her production to thus obtain better earnings. She needs to invest in ingredients, but it is a question of capital. For this reason she is applying to Yehu Microfinance for a loan that will permit her to buy corn, corn husks, vegetables, firewood, etc. 

Elizabeth is very responsible and has impeccable morals. She guarantees the payment of the debt and at the same time is confident that she will be able to give her family a better life.

loans.use: to buy corn, corn husks, vegetables, firewood.

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en:
Caroline lives in Kisauni with her husband. She dreams of a promising future in which she is able to provide her family with the potential for success. Her family is the motivation behind her work of selling lesos (African women's wrap cloth). The business is located in her home and she sells for cash to passersby in her area as well as to neighbors, family members, and friends. They are familiar with the products that Caroline sells and are loyal to her business. 

Caroline's goal is to achieve sustainable growth and, in this way, improve her family's income. Her biggest challenge is to build up enough working capital to be able to grow her business. With the loan, she wants to purchase bales of clothes for resale.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Omar

texts.en:
Omar, 33 years old, lives together with his life partner and his five children. He is a teacher by profession and is a person who is very dedicated to offering quality services in teaching. He also manages a charcoal selling business where he has hired a gentleman to operate on his behalf. He has one year of experience in the business and that has brought him great benefits, because he improves his work day by day.  

Omar is a man devoted to his work, motivated, always looking for better alternatives that will lead toward a more prosperous future for him. He trusts that if he doesn’t stop struggling he will achieve great goals. The requested amount will be used to purchase 15 sacks of charcoal for sale.

loans.use: to purchase 15 sacks of charcoal for sale.

loans.name: Jesukpego Group

texts.fr: «JESUKPEGO» est un groupe composé de trois personnes qui résident dans le même quartier. La représentante du groupe du nom de Valérie (dont la main est levée sur la photo), est âgée de 37 ans. Valérie est mariée à un certain Denis. Le couple a cinq enfants tous scolarisés dont quatre restent à leur charge. Le couple vit ensemble avec les enfants. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la maison. Pour faire face à ses différentes charges, Valérie mène comme activité la vente des charbons de bois dans son quartier. Valérie exerce cette activité depuis une vingtaine d’années et s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Afin de mieux répondre aux exigences de sa clientèle de plus en plus nombreuse et de se faire plus de profits, Valérie sollicite, ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe «JESUKPEGO» un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Les premiers prêts ont été bien remboursés.
texts.en:
"JESUKPEGO" is a group composed of three persons who reside in the same district. The group's representative, Valérie (whose hand is raised in the photo), is 37 years old and married to a man named Denis. The couple have five children, all in school, of whom four remain in their care. The couple live together with their children and jointly ensure that household expenses are covered. 

To cope with her different expenses, Valérie has a business selling charcoal in her district. She has been in this business for about twenty years and gets her supplies from a market in Benin. 

To respond better to the requirements of her burgeoning customer base and to make more profit, Valérie, along with the other members of the group "JESUKPEGO", is requesting a third loan from ALIDé. The first two loans were indeed paid back.

loans.use: to buy charcoal

loans.name: Selina

texts.en: Selina has operated a real estate [management] business for the past seven years and she recently started a charcoal-selling business. With the aim of bolstering her ability to stock up and satisfy the requirements of her customers, she has requested and obtained financial aid from Yehu. This financial aid will help her contribute to her children's education and to meet her own needs. Selina plans to purchase 20 sacks of charcoal for sale. Her aim is to buy a plot of land and construct a rental house in the future.

loans.use: to purchase 20 sacks of charcoal for sale.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is an entrepreneur who has made progress in her goal thanks to her capacity for work and her love for her family, which consists of her husband and three children. 

She is the owner of a business, through which she generates income for the family by selling cooked food, which she began to do five years ago. 

The reason she is asking for a Kiva loan is to buy bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and rice and to establish a poultry business with which she will be able to get substantial discounts by buying in large volume. This is the groundwork for the success of her Kiva loan that has her enthused and dreaming.

loans.use: to buy bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, rice and to establish a poultry business.

loans.name: Justine

texts.en:
Justine lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has three children, and all her children go to school. She also takes care of one additional family member. She lives in her own house and the family has access to electricity but not to piped water. Her major monthly expenses includes include rent, power and school fees.

Justine operates a beauty salon in a shop. She sells her products on a retail basis. She has been in this business for the last 15 years. She works seven days a week. 

She has requested a loan of 800,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT – SACCO to buy braids, weaves, treatments, and oils. 

Her major business challenges are transportation and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations are to own a bridal salon and also to buy a plot of land.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of cream relaxers, braids, weaves and hair treatments.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy various goods such as lotions, soap, clothes, etc. for resale.

loans.name: Banzi

texts.en:
Banzi is a businessman living with his family in a a rental house that has both electricity and piped water. 

He has been operating a retail shop for the last two years with support from his wife. He is now 36 years old and has three children attending school. 

Banzi is honest and industrious in his daily duties because he wants to uplift his living conditions and provide for his children's basic needs and education. 

With his profit from the business, he plans to invest in expanding the business by adding more stock. In order to achieve his business goal, Banzi has applied for a loan through Yehu, a longstanding Kiva partner, to purchase flour, sodas, detergents, and cooking oil. He believes that through his hard work and perseverance he will be able to attain a better standard of living someday.

loans.use: to purchase flour, sodas, detergents, and cooking oil.

loans.name: Albert

texts.en:
Albert is an Egyptian man from one of the two most vulnerable ethnic minority communities of Central Albania. He is forty-eight years old, married and has four children, all grownups. Albert is considered one of the pioneers in his city in the business of second-hand items. Over twenty years ago, with the collapse of the communist regime, this business was not even known in Albania, yet many talented Egyptians, with Albert being one of them, left the country illegally in search of a business model. Very soon, they found their ways of bringing to their country used items that were so much in need then and even nowadays.

Albert never needed a loan until recently when he planned on expanding his business and of course earning more profit through buying/selling textile raw material and fabrics and also household appliances this time. 

Albert thanks VisionFund Albania’s staff for the good work they have been doing at reaching out and helping the vulnerable community, and also Kiva for giving them the opportunity to raise money through its lenders.

loans.use: To purchase textile raw materials and fabrics and also household appliances

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy various goods such as: lotions, soap, water, Fanta, etc. for resale.

loans.name: Ravasco

texts.en:
He used his previous loan to expand his existing business of selling firewood and adding on paraffin.  Today he is requesting a new loan to buy paraffin for resale. This would allow him to meet his customers' needs.

Ravasco hopes that through Kiva many people will continue to get support so they can get ahead with their projects and improve their living conditions and those of their nuclear family -- a message he wanted to give his lenders.

loans.use: to buy paraffin for resale.

loans.name: Efua

texts.en: Efua sells petty goods in Ayensudu, near Elmina. She is married to a driver and has four children. Efua has been selling petty goods for 20 years. She is responsible for paying her children's school fees. Her loan will be used to buy petty goods in bulk. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy petty goods in bulk.

loans.name: Adjoa

texts.en: Adjoa sells oil creams and saucepans in Ayensudu, near Elmina. She is divorced and has two children. Adjoa has been operating her business for 20 years. She is responsible for paying her children's school fees. Her loan will be used to buy oil creams and saucepans to sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to finance her children's educations.

loans.use: To buy oil creams and saucepans to sell.

loans.name: Tumaini

texts.en:
Tumaini is 34 years of age, single, and a mother to four children. She lives in a rental house with her children. She earns a living through the sale of fish.

To increase her working capital, in light of her dual concern to meet customer demand and strengthen her business, Tumaini has sought assistance from Yehu. She has collaborated with the institution for 24 months, and she has asked for a loan to purchase fish and cooking oil. 

Tumaini sells on a cash and retail basis to a customer base mainly comprised of women. With this loan, she hopes to make a monthly profit of 10,000 Kenyan shillings (KES), which will help her to meet the household expenses and improve her living standards.

loans.use: to purchase fish and cooking oil.

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella lives in Kisauni, Mombasa. She works every day because her dream is to have a store that is well known in her town. In order to do this, she sells household consumptions to her retailers as wholesale. With this, she has managed to save and invest in another business that has provided the opportunity to generate new income. 

The lack of working capital in the face of Stella’s dreams are her biggest challenge. This is why she has turned to Kiva credit for her first loan with Yehu Microfinance Trust. 

With her Kiva credit she will buy bundles of wheat flour, sugar, maize flour and beans, which are in high demand. Her loan should be successful because her sales are based on customer orders. What she buys has a fast turnover, which causes her working capital to turn quickly and therefore increase her profits. Choosing good customers would increase the recovery of her capital and thereby her earnings.

loans.use: to buy bundles of wheat flour, sugar, maize flour, beans.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a new motorcycle for his business.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is a married woman who lives with her husband and three children.

Because of her need to generate an income so that she can improve her family’s well-being, Lydia began her business of selling charcoal. Her main clients are the neighboring community members.  

Lydia is requesting her second loan through Yehu Microfinance Trust, an organization she has been a part of for one year and that made it possible for her to set up her business, in order to give it a more comfortable environment. 

She will use the money from her first Kiva loan to buy sacks of charcoal for resale in order to increase the opportunities in the market, such as responding to new customers that have been referred by the current buyers and those whose attention she wants to capture.

loans.use: to buy sacks of charcoal.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes lives in Kisauni, Kenya.  She is a good entrepreneur and for one year she has owned her own business. She operates a charcoal business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. 

Today her dreams continue to grow and her goals are to continue increasing her income so that she can expand to a wholesale charcoal shop and be very successful.

Her market is growing and so is the amount of capital that she needs to continue providing the products her customers demand. This will be her first loan from Yehu Microfinance Trust. She will use it to buy sacks of charcoal and will promote her business with special discounts. Agnes wants to offer great prices to her customers so that she can continue earning their loyalty, and this is why she will be successful in investing her credit Kiva loan in her business.

loans.use: to buy sacks of charcoal.

loans.name: Hanife

texts.en:
Hanife is 44 years old, very caring and a hardworking lady who is respected by almost everyone in the region. She is married and has three children; all of them attend school. 

Hanife is a nurse and exercises her profession in four villages. Note here that since the region where she resides and works is dominated by rocky mountain ranges, the life for people is very hard. They get sick all the time from various causes: the cold, the lack of nutrients, infections and the list goes on. This keeps Hanife busy and fit as well because she walks from village to village to help people she has been assigned to.

In addition to her nursing job, Hanife has been running her own dairy business over the past 13 years. The income from both job and business haven’t been that bad; however, she can only feed the children with the earnings, according to her.

Hanife is requesting a Kiva loan this time to store up feed for livestock and wants to thank Kiva and VFA for the opportunity she has been granted.

loans.use: To buy feed for livestock.

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en: Ekua sells kenkey (fermented maize dough) in Emissa Krom, near Cape Coast. Ekua has received a junior high school level education. She is married and has no children. Her husband is a farmer. Ekua has been selling kenkey for the past three years. She is responsible for helping her husband in paying for household expenses. Whatever she has left, she saves for the future and reinvests in the business. Her loan will be used to buy maize for the production of kenkey. She hopes to use the new profits to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy maize for the production of kenkey.

loans.name: Esi

texts.en:
Esi is married and has three children. She has received schooling through middle school. Esi sells cooked rice and cloth in Ayensudu, near Elmina, which she has done for seven years. Her husband is a pastor. 

Esi uses her income to assist in paying for household expenses. She will use the loan to purchase more rice and cloth in bulk. With her new profits, Esi plans to continue to support her family and help her children.

loans.use: to purchase more rice and cloth, in bulk.

loans.name: Efua

texts.en: Efua is married and has four children. She sells banku (fermented maize and cassava dough) in Emissa Krom, near Cape Coast, which she has done for the past two years. Her husband is a farmer. Efua uses her income to pay for her children's school fees. Efua will use the loan to purchase maize and cassava. With the new profits, Efua plans to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase maize and cassava.

loans.name: Badeya Group

texts.fr:
Mme SOLANGE représente le groupe BADEYA. Mariée, elle est mère de 03 enfants. Le plus âgé a 17ans et le moins âgé a 06ans. Les 03 vont à l’école et elle a 03 personnes en charge.

Mme fait la restauration (vente d’atiéké) depuis 10ans. Elle s’approvisionne au marché de KILWIN. Ses clients sont les habitants du quartier.

Elle veut s’acheter 10sachets d’atiéké, 03cartons de poisson et 01bidon de 20l d’huile.

Avec ses bénéfices, elle désire agrandir son commerce. Mme ambitionne améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Ms. SOLANGE represents the group BADEYA. Married, she is the mother of three children. The oldest is 17 years old, and the youngest is 6. The three go to school. She has three persons to support. 

Ms. SOLANGE has been in the restaurant business selling atiéké (cassava couscous) for ten years. She gets her supplies at the KILWIN market. Her customers are the inhabitants of the district.

She wants to purchase 10 pouches of atiéké, 3 boxes of fish, and a 20-liter container of oil. 

With the profits, she would like to expand her business. Ms. SOLANGE  has the ambition to improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to buy 10 pouches of atiéké, 3 boxes of  fish, and a 20-liter container of oil for her restaurant

loans.name: Régina

texts.fr: Agée de 34 ans, Régina est mariée et mère de deux enfants âgés de 12 ans et de  09 ans. Tous sont scolarisés dans une école de la ville. Elle a une baraque où elle vend de l'haricot, du soja, du mil et de l'arachide depuis des années puis s'approvisionne dans l'un des marchés du Bénin. Dans le but de renforcer son capital et de répondre favorablement aux demandes de ses clients, Régina a fait recours au micro crédit de Finadev. Ce crédit lui permettra d'accroitre son revenu additionnel et de participer à l'éducation de ses enfants. Régina envisage acheter une bâchée en vue de diminuer les coûts du transport.
texts.en:
Régina is 34 years old, married, and the mother of two children ages 12 and 9 years old.  Both her children attend a local school.

She has a stall where she has been selling beans, soy, millet and groundnut for several years.  She buys her goods from a market in Benin. 

In order to strengthen her capital and to favorably meet her customers' demand, Régina has turned to Finadev to obtain a micro-credit.

This loan will allow her to increase her additional income and to take part in her children's education.  She is planning to buy a pick-up truck  in order to reduce her transportation costs.

loans.use: to buy five bags of beans, five bags of soy, three bags of millet and two bags of groundnuts.

loans.name: Sedjrogande Group

texts.fr: Le groupe SEDJROGANDE est composé de trois personnes qui résident dans un même quartier. La représentante du groupe, du nom de Sylvie Edwige est celle qui a la main levée sur la photo. Sylvie Edwige est âgée de 30 ans et est mariée à un certain Richard. Sylvie Edwige n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Le couple a trois enfants, tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Sylvie Edwige vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants. Le couple se partage les différentes charges de la maison. Pour contribuer aux différents besoins de la famille, Sylvie Edwige vend depuis cinq ans, des céréales dans son quartier. Cette activité lui permet de répondre sans grande difficulté à ses besoins. Sylvie Edwige s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son chiffre d’affaires et son revenu, Sylvie Edwige sollicite ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe SEDJROGANDE, un crédit auprès de ALIDé. Ce prêt leur permettra de rehausser le niveau de leur activité et d’accroître leur clientèle et leur revenu.
texts.en:
The SEDJROGANDE group is made up of three people who live in the same neighborhood. Sylvie Edwige, the group's representative, is the person with her hand raised in the photo. She is 30 years old and is married to a man named Richard. Sylvie Edwige did not go to school. The couple has three children, all of whom have received schooling and live in their care. Sylvie Edwige lives with her husband and her children. The couple shares the various household expenses.

In order to contribute to the various needs of her family, Sylvie Edwige has been selling grains in her neighborhood for the past five years. This business allows her to meet her family's needs without difficulty. Sylvie Edwige stocks up at a market in Benin.

Striving to satisfy her customers and increase her sales and her revenue, Sylvie Edwige, along with the other members of the SEDJROGANDE group, is seeking a loan from ALIDé. The loan will allow them to expand their business and increase both their customer base and revenue.

loans.use: to buy grains

loans.name: Elvira

texts.es: La Sra. Elvira  tiene 42 años tiene dos hijos de las edades de 16 y 13 años, ella se dedica a la confección de prendas de  vestir tiene su taller de costura en la zona de Alcochen,   este préstamo es su segunda secuencia dentro de la institución, la Sra. Elvira  va a usar este préstamo  para capital de trabajo (compra de maquina over y recta) para su negocio, la razón para solicitar este préstamo es hacer crecer el negocio, la Sra.  Elvira enfrenta retos en su negocio que son  la competencia del mercado y la falta de maquinaria para la confección de prendas de vestir y va a utilizar los beneficios en seguir comprando las maquinas que le hacen falta y así de esta manera  incrementar su capital de trabajo, su deseo para su  negocio es tener un taller de costura más grande contratar personal que le ayude a confeccionar sus prendas de vestir, la Sra. Elvira es un apersona muy trabajadora se siente feliz y agradecida con la institución por el apoyo brindado.
texts.en:
42-year old Sra. Elvira has two children aged 16 and 13. She earns her living making clothes and has a workshop in the area of Alcochen. This will be her second loan with this institution, and she plans to use the money to buy a special kind of sewing machine for her business. The reason for seeking another loan is so that she can grow her business.

The challenges that Elvira faces are competition and the lack of machines to make the clothing. She will use any profits to buy the machines she still lacks and in this way increase her working capital.  Her future wishes include owning a bigger workshop and employing people to help her make the clothing. Elvira is a hardworking person who is happy and grateful to the institution for the support it offers her.

loans.use: Buy a special kind of sewing machine

loans.name: Christine

texts.en: Christine is married and resides with her six children in Kisauni, Coast Province, Kenya. She has been involved in a grocery business for more than twenty years. Her husband, who is a mason by profession, helps her run the business. Four of her children are attending school. In order to improve her family’s finances, Christine is requesting a loan of 15,000 KES to purchase sacks of vegetables and fruits to sell. This money will help her run the business and earn more income to support the family. In the future, she would like to expand her business and help her children achieve their dreams.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of vegetables and fruits to sell.

loans.name: Ama

texts.en: Ama sells sauce pans and other cooking utensils in Emissa Krom, near Cape Coast. Ama has gone to school through junior high school. She is married and has three children. Her husband is a carpenter. Ama has been selling sauce pans and other cooking utensils for six years. She is responsible for paying her children's school fees. Her loan will be used to buy pots, pans, and cooking utensils in bulk. She hopes to use the new profits to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy pots, pans, and cooking utensils in bulk.

loans.name: Mourice

texts.en:
Mourice is married man and he has three children. He resides in his own house with access to electricity and piped water. His monthly expenses include food for the family. 

For the past 2 years, Mourice has operated a food stall business. He has applied for a loan of 40,000 KES from Yehu Microfinance Trust to buy more bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and bundles of fish, as well as cooking oil. Mourice sells to all categories of people and works seven days a week. His major business challenges include seasonality and transportation of commodities from Mombasa town to his food stall. Mourice hope to see his business expand to a restaurant in the future.

loans.use: to buy more bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and bundles of fish, as well as cooking oil.

loans.name: Louise

texts.fr: Louise, âgé 48 ans, est mariée et mère de cinq enfants dont deux vont encore à l'école. Spécialisée dans la vente du maïs et du soja depuis quelques années et elle s'approvisionne dans l'un des marchés du Bénin. En vue d'augmenter son chiffre d'affaire et de satisfaire les besoins de ses clients, elle a sollicité et a obtenu un micro crédit à Finadev en vue de maximiser son intérêt et de participer à la scolarisation de ses enfants. Elle envisage développer son activité afin d'avoir la part du marché et d'aider son mari à creuser un puits dans leur maison.
texts.en:
Louise, aged 48, is married and the mother of five children, of whom two go to school. Specialized in selling corn and soybeans for a few years, she gets her supplies from one of the markets in Benin. 

With the aim of increasing her sales and satisfying the needs of her customers, she requested and obtained a micro-loan from Finadev to make the most of her investments and to help with her children's schooling costs. She envisions developing her business to have a large part of the market and to assist her husband in drilling a well at their house.

loans.use: to buy 10 sacks of corn and 10 of soybeans

loans.name: Vivogbe Group

texts.fr: VIVOGBE est un groupe de trois personnes, dont les membres résident dans le même quartier. La représentante du groupe, Clotilde (dont la main est levée sur la photo), est âgée de 32 ans et est mariée à un peintre du nom de Cyrille. Le couple a trois enfants tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Clotilde vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants. Clotilde assure avec son mari, les diverses charges de la maison. Depuis une vingtaine d'années environs, Clotilde vend des produits cosmétiques et des sacs par le système de distribution. Clotilde s’approvisionne dans un marché du Benin. C’est la deuxième fois que Clotilde et les autres membres du groupe VIVOGBE sollicitent l’appui financier de ALIDé en vue de renforcer leur fonds de roulement et leur activité et de mieux répondre aux exigences de leur clientèle. Le crédit reçu antérieurement a été bien remboursé.
texts.en:
VIVOGBE is a group of three persons who reside in the same district. The group's representative, Clotilde (whose hand is raised in the photo), is 32 years old and married to a painter named Cyrille. The couple have three children, all in school and in their care. She lives together with her husband and children. Along with her husband, she ensures that the diverse household expenses are covered. 

For about twenty years, Clotilde has been selling cosmetic products and bags via the distribution system. She gets her supplies from a market in Benin.

This is the second time Clotilde and the other members of the group VIVOGBE are requesting financial support from ALIDé with the aim of bolstering their working capital and their businesses and responding better to the requirements of their customers. The previous loan was indeed repaid.

loans.use: to buy cosmetic products to sell

loans.name: Sagesse Group

texts.fr: Le groupe SAGESSE est composé de trois personnes qui résident dans un même quartier. C'est la quatrième fois que ce groupe sollicite l'aide financier de ALIDé, afin d'élever le niveau de son activité. La représentante du groupe, du nom de Catherine est celle qui a la main levée sur la photo. Catherine est âgée de 39 ans et est mariée à un certain Evariste. Catherine a peu fréquenté l’école et s’est arrêté au niveau secondaire. Le couple a quatre enfants tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Le couple assure ensemble les divers besoins du ménage. Pour contribuer aux différents besoins de la famille, Catherine vend depuis neuf ans des savons par le système de distribution. Cette activité lui permet de répondre sans grande difficulté à ses charges. Catherine s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son chiffre d’affaires et son revenu, Catherine sollicite ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe SAGESSE, un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
texts.en:
The group SAGESSE comprises three persons who reside in the same district. This is the fourth time this group has requested financial aid from ALIDé to boost business. The group's representative, Catherine, is the one in the photo with her hand raised. She is 39 years old and married to a man named Evariste. She has very little schooling and dropped out of secondary school. The couple have four children, all in school and in their care. The couple jointly ensure that the diverse household needs are met. 

To help with different family needs, Catherine has been selling soaps via the distribution system. This business enables her to cover her expenses. Christine gets her supplies from a market in Benin. 

Seeking to satisfy her customers and to grow her sales and revenues, Catherine, along with the other members of the group SAGESSE, is requesting a fourth loan from ALIDé. The previous loans were indeed paid back.

loans.use: to buy soaps

loans.name: Loyce

texts.en: Loyce used her previous loan to buy clothes to sell, as well as cement, sand and timber to renovate her rental houses. Today she is requesting a new loan to buy, wholesale and in cash, bundles of clothes for both men and women to increase her stock. This would allow her to have a stock of inventory, receive discounts for quick payment, and offer a variety of clothes to her customers who have become accustomed to her having the best selection of clothes every day.

loans.use: to buy bindles of clothes for both men and women.

loans.name: Efua

texts.en: Efua is single and has seven children. She sells bread, doughnuts, and pots and pans in Emissa Krom, near Cape Coast and has done this for the past eight years. Efua uses her income to pay for her children's school fees as well as all other household/living expenses. Efua will use the loan to purchase flour and sugar in bulk as well as pots and pans for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Efua plans to support herself and her family.

loans.use: to purchase flour and sugar in bulk as well as pots and pans for sale.

loans.name: Mariamu

texts.en: Mariamu is 39 years old and  is raising five children. To provide a source of income for the family, she is involved in selling food stuffs in the open air. The business was started in 2003 with an initial sum of 2,000 KES and today her capital has almost quadrupled. Mariamu is a divorced woman who has to work extra hard to provide for her children. Thanks to her efforts and dedication, all are in school.  In order to further develop her business, she requested a loan in the amount of 10,000 KES from the Yehu to buy potatoes, cooking oil, and wheat flour. She plans to invest the earnings into a continuing expansion of her business by building a stall.

loans.use: to buy potatoes, cooking oil, and wheat flour.

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine, 38, lives in Mombasa city. She has two children, a 7-year-old and a 3-year-old, who attend elementary school. She’s a merchant. With her own efforts and with Yehu loans, Christine has been growing socially and economically. She currently operates a salon, producing income to support her children and to pay household expenses. She also gets help from her spouse.

Christine is very responsible. She demonstrated responsibility through helping her husband in the household expenses. She’s now requesting a loan to buy some chemicals and other beauty products.

loans.use: to buy some chemicals and other beauty products.

loans.name: Hajara

texts.en:
Hajara lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married with five children and all go to school. She also takes care of two additional family members. Hajara sells green bananas and charcoal at the market. She sells her products on a wholesale and retail basis. She has been in business for the last 5 years. She also gets additional income from rental houses. She works 6 days a week. 

She has requested a loan of 1,200,000 Uganda Shillings from MCDT – SACCO to buy bunches of green bananas and bags of charcoal. Her major business challenges are transportation and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations are to buy a delivery van and also to educate her children up to university level. She lives in her own house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her major expenses include power and school fees.

loans.use: To buy bunches of green bananas and bags of charcoal

loans.name: Enagnon Group

texts.fr: ENAGNON est un groupe de trois personnes, dont les membres résident dans le même quartier. La représentante du groupe, Maroufatou (dont la main est levée sur la photo), est âgée de 34 ans et est mariée à un certain Ferdinand. Le couple a deux enfants, tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Maroufatou vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari et assure ensemble avec son mari, les différentes charges de la maison. Depuis près d’une dizaine d’années, Maroufatou vend des céréales (maïs, riz et de la farine de manioc) dans son quartier. Maroufatou s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. C’est la troisième fois que Maroufatou et les autres membres du groupe ENAGNON sollicitent l’appui financier de ALIDé en vue de renforcer leur fonds de roulement et leur activité afin de mieux répondre aux exigences de leur clientèle. Les crédits reçus antérieurement ont été bien remboursés.
texts.en:
ENAGNON is a group of three persons who reside in the same district. The group's representative, Maroufatou (whose hand is raised in the photo), is 34 years old and married to a man named Ferdinand. The couple have two children, both in school and in their care. She lives together with her husband and children, and along with her husband, she ensures that the different household expenses are covered. 

For about ten years, Maroufatou has been selling grains (corn, rice, and cassava flour) in her district. She gets her supplies from a market in Benin.

This is the third time Maroufatou and the other members of the group ENAGNON have requested financial support from ALIDé with the aim of bolstering their working capital and their businesses and responding better to the requirements of their customers. The previous loans were indeed repaid.

loans.use: to buy grains (corn, rice, and some cassava flour)

loans.name: Minankpon Group

texts.fr: Le groupe MINANKPON est composé de trois personnes qui résident dans un même quartier. C'est la troisième fois que ce groupe sollicite l'aide financier de ALIDé, afin d'élever le niveau de son activité. La représentante du groupe, du nom de Marie-Claire est celle qui a la main levée sur la photo. Marie-Claire est âgée de 32 ans et est mariée à un certain Bahougobi. Marie-Claire n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Le couple a deux enfants, tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Marie-Claire vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants. Le couple se partage les différentes charges de la maison. Pour contribuer aux différents besoins de la famille, Marie-Claire vend depuis dix ans, des cartes de recharges et des condiments dans son quartier. Cette activité lui permet de répondre sans grande difficulté à ses besoins. Marie-Claire s’approvisionne dans une région du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son chiffre d’affaires et son revenu, Marie-Claire sollicite ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe MINANKPON, un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Ce prêt leur permettra de rehausser le niveau de leur activité et d’accroître leur clientèle et leur revenu. Les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
texts.en:
The MINANKPON group consists of three people who live in the same neighborhood.  It is the third time that this group is requesting financial support from Alidé, in order to increase its level of activity.

The group's representative, Marie-Claire, is the one raising her hand in the photo.  She is 32 years old and married to a man named Bahougobi.  She never attended school.

Marie-Claire and Bahougobi have two children, both in school and their dependents.  Marie-Claire lives with her husband and children.  The couple takes care of the various household expenses together.

For the past ten years, and in order to meet the family's various needs, Marie-Claire has been selling phone recharge cards and condiments in her neighborhood.  Thanks to this activity, she is able to meet her own needs without much difficulty.

Marie-Claire buys her goods in one of the regions of Benin.  In order to meet her customers' needs, and to increase her turnover and income, Marie-Claire is requesting a third loan from Alidé, together with the other members of the MINANKPON group.

This loan will allow them to boost their level of activity and to increase their customer base and income.  Previous loans have been duly repaid.

loans.use: to buy some condiments.

loans.name: Edgar

texts.es: El Sr. Edgar tiene 33 años y es soltero con 2 hijos que se encuentran en edad escolar, el se dedica   la fabricación de artesanías en cuero en su taller que se encuentra en la zona Avaroa,  este préstamo es su primera secuencia dentro de la institución y va a usar este préstamo para la  compra de cuero de res para realizar su artesanías,  su razón para solicitar este préstamo es incrementar producción. El Sr. Edgar enfrenta retos en su negocio que son la competencia y va a utilizar los beneficios para incrementar su capital de trabajo, su deseo con el tiempo es poder tener un taller grande y exportar sus artesanías a distintos países que vean la calidad de su trabajo.
texts.en:
Edgar, age 33, is single and has two school age children.  He makes leather handicrafts at his workshop in the Avaroa area.

This is his first loan cycle with the institution.  He will use the loan to buy leather to make his handicrafts.  His reason for requesting this loan is to increase production.  Edgar faces challenges in his business due to the competition.  He will use the profits to increase his working capital.

His wish is that, in time, he will be able to have a large shop and export his handicrafts to different countries so that they see the quality of his work.

loans.use: to buy leather.

loans.name: Nasibu

texts.en:
Nasibu used his previous loan to expand his existing video shop business and purchased a plasma television. Now he is requesting a new loan to buy a digital station television (DSTV). This would allow him to have many customers watching soccer games and various channels.

Nasibu hopes that through Kiva, many people will continue to get support so they can get ahead with their projects and improve their living conditions and those of their nuclear families. This is a message he wanted to give his lenders.

loans.use: to buy a digital station television (DSTV) for his video shop.

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is a single mother of three children who are currently in school. She is busy working in her food stall selling a variety of food stuffs. She has been running this stall for the last three years, operating it from outside her home. Asha has been always struggling hard to ensure that her children do not lack any basic needs, now that she knows that she is the breadwinner.
Asha has already established a good customer base. Demand for more dishes has increased and so she is requesting a loan in the amount of Ksh 20,000 to purchase more ingredients such as wheat flour, sugar, and meat. Doing this will enable her to meet her customer needs.

loans.use: to purchase more ingredients such as wheat flour, sugar, and meat for her food stall.

loans.name: Yaqueline

texts.en: Miss Yaqueline belongs to the community bank "MINIBANK" Arariwa Association. She is 30 years old, married and has one daughter. Yaqueline is a nurse and works at a clinic in the city of Cusco. This time she needs the loan for home maintenance. She wants to buy paint, wood, cement, ceramic and other things.

loans.use: to buy items for home maintenance.

loans.name: Angélique

texts.fr: Angélique est mariée et mère de trois enfants scolarisés dont le plus âgé a 10 ans et le moins âgé a 03 ans. Elle vend des produits alimentaires et des produits de beauté depuis des années dans une boutique sise à son domicile. Elle fait ses ravitaillements dans l'un des marchés de la sous région. Expérimentée dans le crédit, elle a sollicité et a obtenu un concours financier auprès de Finadev en d'accroître sa capacité d'approvisionnement et de combler les besoins de ses clients. Ce concours financier lui permettra de renforcer son fonds de commerce et participer à l'éducation de ses enfants. Elle souhaiterait agrandir sa boutique et assurer la bonne santé de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Angélique is married and the mother of three children, who are in school. The oldest is 10, and the youngest is 3. She has been selling grocery items and beauty products for years at a shop located in her home. She resupplies herself from one of the markets in the sub-region. 

Experienced with loans, she requested and obtained financial assistance from Finadev to increase her capacity to resupply herself and to fulfill the needs of her customers. This financial assistance will enable her to bolster her business capital and to help with her children's education. She would like to expand her shop and to ensure her children's healthcare is covered.

loans.use: to buy 3 boxes of  canned tomatoes, 18 boxes of macaroni, a box of milk, 5 boxes of ointment, and a box of perfume

loans.name: Jose Ovidio

texts.es:
José, está solicitando un nuevo préstamo para poderlo invertir en la compra de madera para utilizar en la carpintería, dentro de su compra destaca la madera de cedro, manera de pino, que son las más utilizadas para la elaboración de muebles, este préstamo le dará los recursos económicos para que puedan mantener en el taller un buen nivel de materia prima y así atender las demandas de los clientes.

El préstamo anterior le brindó una mejor condición de trabajo en la carpintería, logró comprarse herramientas que son las que utiliza actualmente para la elaboración de los muebles, esto ha motivado a que José continúe trabajando para poder mantener una buena producción en el negocio y poder crecer.
texts.en:
Jose is requesting a new loan to enable him to invest in the purchase of wood to utilize in his carpentry. Especially important in this purchase is ceder and pine wood, which he utilizes to make furniture. This loan  will give him the necessary economic resources to maintain his workshop with an ample level of prime materials and thus meet his customers' demands.

Jose's previous loan provided him with better conditions for his carpentry work. He was able to buy the tools that he now uses to make furniture. This has motivated Jose to continue working, maintaining a good level of production, to be able to expand his business.

loans.use: to buy pine and ceder wood to make furniture.

loans.name: Eri

texts.en:
Eri is in his early 30s and is from a town of approximately 10,000 residents in central eastern Albania. Eri is known for his excellent customer service skills and the hard work he has been pouring into his bakery business for the past 13 years to establish and nurture a steady clientele. Eri learned baking skills in Greece at a very young age and he is extremely appreciative to his Greek employer for providing him with the opportunity to learn such skills that are very much in demand in his own town. Eri started the business at a very young age and has thrived since. He is proud of and happy with the work and the progress he has made. He is hoping to do well as a family man, too, by creating a family of his own very soon.
Eri is requesting a loan for the first time to buy some spare parts for the vehicle that he uses for the delivery of baked goods in the suburban areas. This month that he has not been delivering any goods because he hasn’t had the vehicle. The demand and profits have dropped considerably.
He believes that with some support from Kiva lenders, he will be able to buy the vehicle parts and offer the services he used to.

loans.use: to buy spare parts for the vehicle he uses to deliver baked goods

loans.name: Rachelle

texts.fr:
Rachelle est une femme de 34 ans, célibataire et mére de 2 enfants dont lâge varie entre 10 et 12 ans tous scolarisés. Elle est commerçante dans un marché de la capitale depuis 16 ans.De 
par son expérience, la bonne qualité de ses produits et les prix pratiqués lui ont valu une renommée sans pareil. Devenue de plus en plus sollicitée, elle est confrontée à un deséquilibre entre l'offre et la demande. ce crédit lui permettra de répondre à une demande grandissante. les bénéfices générés lui permettront de réinvestire  dans son activité( achat en gro des régimes de banane plantains) de continuer à soutenir ses enfants dans leur scolarité et subvenir aux besoins de sa famille.
texts.en:
Rachelle is a 34-year-old woman, unmarried, and the mother of two children, 10 to 12 years old, who are both in school. She has been a merchant at a market in the capital for sixteen years. Due to her experience, the good quality of her products, and practical prices, she has earned unmatched fame.

More and more in demand, she is confronted with an imbalance between supply and demand. This loan will enable her to respond to the growing demand. The profits generated will enable her to reinvest in her business (buying bunches of plantains in bulk) to continue to support her children in covering their schooling costs and to  meet the needs of her family.

loans.use: to buy bunches of plantains

loans.name: Sedjro Group

texts.fr: SEDJRO est un groupe de trois personnes, dont les membres résident dans le même quartier. La représentante du groupe, Christine (dont la main est levée sur la photo), est âgée de 39 ans et est mariée à un certain Joachim. Le couple a un enfant, scolarisé et à leur charge. Christine n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Christine vit ensemble avec son enfant et son mari et assure ensemble avec son mari, les différentes charges de la maison. Depuis près de quatorze ans, Christine vend du pain de façon ambulante. Christine s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin.  C’est la deuxième fois que Christine et les autres membres du groupe SEDJRO sollicitent l’appui financier de ALIDé en vue de renforcer leur fonds de roulement et leur activité et de mieux répondre aux exigences de leur clientèle. Le crédit reçu antérieurement a été bien remboursé.
texts.en:
SEDJRO is a group of three persons whose members reside in the same district. The group's representative, Christine (whose hand is raised in the photo), is 39 years old and married to a man named Joachim. The couple have one child, in school and in their care. Christine did not attend school. She lives together with her child and husband, and along with her husband, she ensures that the different household expenses are covered. 

For nearly fourteen years, Christine has been selling bread door to door. She gets her supplies from a market in Benin. 

This is the second time that Christine and the other member of the group SEDJRO have requested financial support from ALIDé with the aim of bolstering their working capital and responding further to the requirements of their customers. The loans received previously were indeed repaid.

loans.use: to buy bread

loans.name: Joyas Del Pacifico Group

texts.es:
Este Banco Comunal se llama “Joyas del Pacifico” está conformado por 18 emprendedores quienes se dedican a diferentes rubros, entre los cuales se encuentran; ventas de ensaladas, venta de ropa, bazar, costuras, librería, almacén, venta de productos de belleza, kiosko, venta de empanadas, servicios entre otros. Todos ellos pertenecientes a la ciudad de Valparaíso.
Maria Eliana, delegada de Educación del grupo del Banco Comunal, quien en la foto se encuentra sentada en primera fila, ocupando el segundo lugar de derecha a izquierda, viste un chaleco de color negro, usa una falda con franjas de colores blanco, lila y verde, su cabello es de color oscuro y lo usa suelto, en sus brazos carga a su nieta.
Ella se dedica a la venta de productos de aseo, a la vez realiza costuras (confección de pantalones) y tejido, en la venta de productos de aseo se dedica desde hace 1 año, y a las costuras y tejidos desde hace mas de 6 años. Comenta que trabaja de lunes a  sábado y los domingos los deja para ir a la Iglesia con sus nietas, trabaja desde su casa y algunas veces ofrece sus productos de puerta en puerta, su horario de trabajo lo distribuye de acuerdo a su disponibilidad. 
La mercadería que va necesitando la compra en liquidadoras donde venden productos de aseo, las lanas y telas en distribuidoras todo en la ciudad de Valparaíso a bajo costo, además ya la conocen y le realizan descuento al momento de comprar.
Con el crédito comprará artículos de aseo, lanas de varios colores, telas e hilos.
Una de las metas de Maria Eliana es tener un taller de costuras en su casa, así generar mayores ingresos y optar a una mejor calidad de vida.
Maria Eliana vive junto a sus 3 nietas de 7, 4 y 1 año de edad. Sus sueños a nivel familiar es darle un buen pasar a sus nietas y un buen futuro para sus estudios.
Ella está muy contenta y agradecida de  la oportunidad brindada por Fondo Esperanza, ya que le permitirá invertir en su negocio. Comenta que las capacitaciones han sido fundamentales para su negocio y también para su desarrollo personal, ya que ha aprendido a organizar y distribuir de mejor manera sus ingresos e inversiones. Respecto al grupo del Banco Comunal del cual forma parte, comenta que es excelente muy buena comunicación.
Valparaíso está situado a 120 kilómetros al noroeste de Santiago. Es la capital regional y además sede del poder legislativo del país. Es el primer puerto de la nación y ofrece gran variedad de lugares hermosos y pintorescos, como por ejemplo la casa del poeta Pablo Neruda, ganador del Premio Nobel.
texts.en:
This communal bank is called Joyas del Pacífico and is made up of 18 entrepreneurs who work in different areas, including salad sales, clothing sales, general store, tailoring, bookstore, department store, beauty product sales, kiosk, empanada sales, services, and other things.  All of them are in the city of Valparaíso.

María Eliana, the education delegate of the communal bank group, is seated in the first row in the photo in the second place from the right.  She's wearing a black jacket and a skirt with white, lilac, and green trim.  Her hair is dark and she wears it loose.  She's holding her granddaughter in her arms.

She works selling toiletries and also does tailoring (making pants) and weaving.  She has worked selling toiletries for a year and more than six years tailoring and weaving.  She says she works Monday through Saturday and reserves Sunday for going to church with her grandchildren.  She works from home and sometimes offers her products door-to-door.  She organizes her work schedule according to her availability.

She buys the merchandise she needs from liquidators that sell toiletry products.  She buys the wool and fabric at low prices from distributors in the city of Valparaíso; also, they already know her so they give her a discount when she's making her purchase.

With the loan she will buy toiletries, wool in various colors, fabric, and thread.

One of María Eliana's goals is to have a tailor shop in her home to generate more income and choose a better quality of life.  María Eliana lives with her three grandchildren, ages 7, 4, and 1.  Her dreams for her family are to give her grandchildren a good income and a good future for their studies.

She is very happy about and grateful for the opportunity offered by Fondo Esperanza because it will allow her to invest in her business.  She comments that the trainings have been fundamental for her business and also her personal development because she has learned how to organize and better distribute her income and investments.  With regard to the communal bank group to which she belongs, she says it's excellent with very good communication.

Valparaíso is located 120 kilometers northwest of Santiago.  It's the regional capital and also the seat of the country's legislative branch and the most important port.  It offers a wide variety of pretty and picturesque places, such as the house of the poet Pablo Neruda, winner of the Nobel Prize.

loans.use: to buy toiletries, wool in various colors, fabric, and thread

loans.name: Esperanza Del Crea Group

texts.es:
Este Banco Comunal se llama “Esperanza del Crea” está conformado por 18 emprendedores quienes se dedican a diferentes rubros, entre los cuales se encuentran; venta de verduras, venta de pasteles, venta de ropa, venta de ensaladas, cocinería, pescadería, almacén, venta de frutas y verduras, servicios entre otros. Todos pertenecientes a la ciudad de Talca.
Cesar, presidente del grupo del Banco Comunal, quien en la foto se encuentra en la última fila, ocupando el primer lugar de izquierda a derecha, lleva puesto un chaleco de color azul y un gorro deportivo de color azul.
El se dedica al rubro de pescadería, desde hace 24 años. Comenta que trabaja viernes, sábados y domingos, desde las 06ºº hasta las 14ºº horas, se ubica en la feria con su puesto de pescadería.
La mercadería que v necesitando la compra en el terminal pesquero y otras veces a pescadores artesanales de la zona.
Con el crédito comprará almejas y choritos (frutos del mar conocidos como mariscos). 
Una de las metas de Cesar es continuar con el negocio y poder independizarse para abastecer su negocio solo, para generar mayores ingresos, así con esto optar a una mejor calidad de vida y brindarle un buen pasar a su familia.
Cesar vive junto a su esposa y 2 hijos de 22 y 15 años de edad, quienes se encuentran estudiando. Sus sueños a nivel familiar son darles a su familia lo mejor para que no les falta nada, y a nivel laboral seguir trabajando para su familia.
El se encuentra muy contento y agradecido de la oportunidad brindada por Fondo Esperanza, ya que le permitirá invertir en su negocio. Respecto al grupo del Banco Comunal del cual forma parte, comenta que existe mucha responsabilidad y confianza. Por otro lado las capacitaciones, le han servido para aprender nuevas estrategias de venta y contabilidad.
Talca pertenece a la región del Maule, ubicada en la zona centro del país. Constituye el centro administrativo, económico y cultural de la región, siendo la ciudad más importante del Valle Central chileno. Sobre Talca existe una curiosa referencia en Chile, la frase "Talca, París, y Londres". Entre los mitos al respecto, algunos dicen que es una derivación de la originalmente dicha por un inglés "Talca parece Londres", por la abundante neblina que cubre frecuentemente la ciudad en la temporada invernal, a semejanza de la capital del Reino Unido.
texts.en:
This communal bank’s name is “Esperanza del Crea”.  It is comprised of 18 entrepreneurs who are in a variety of lines of work among which are found selling vegetables, selling cakes, selling clothes, selling salads, cooking, a fish store, store, selling fruits and vegetables, and services, among others.  All of them are from the city of Talca.

Cesar is the president of the communal bank.  In the photo he is in the first person from left to right in the last row.  He is wearing a blue vest and a blue sports cap.  He has been selling fish for 24 years.  He says that he works Fridays, Saturdays, and Sundays from 6:00 a.m. until 2:00 p.m.  He has a fish stand at the fair.  He buys the merchandise that he needs at the fish market, and sometimes he buys from the independent fisherman in the area.

He will use the loan to buy clams and mussels (fruits of the sea known as shellfish).  One of Cesar’s goals is to continue with the business and to be able to become independent in order to stock his business by himself.  He wants to do this to generate more income, to have a better quality of life, and to give his family a good life.

Cesar lives with his wife and their two children, ages 22 and 15.  The children go to school.  His dreams for his family are to give them the best so that they lack nothing.  On a work level, his dream is to continue working for his family.

He is very happy and grateful for the opportunity given to him by Fondo Esperanza because it allows him to invest in his business.  Regarding the communal bank that he is part of, he says there is a lot of responsibility and trust.  Through the trainings he has learned new sales and accounting strategies.

Talca is part of the Maule region located in center of the country. It is the region's administrative, economic, and cultural center and the most important city in Chile's Central Valley. There is an interesting Chilean phrase, "Talca, París, y Londres" [Talca, Paris, London], which some say comes from misstating an English phrase "Talca looks like London," referring to fog that often shrouds Talca during the winter as it does the English capital city.

loans.use: to buy clams and mussels (fruits of the sea known as shellfish).

loans.name: Tierras Coloradas Group

texts.es:
Este Banco Comunal se llama “Tierras Coloradas” está conformado por 17 emprendedoras quienes se dedican a diferentes rubros, entre los cuales se encuentran; confección de cojines y cortinas de baño. Venta de zapatos usados, venta de ropa, feriantes, almacén, florería, restaurant, artesanía, servicios entre otros. Todos pertenecientes a la ciudad de Temuco.
Vannesa, tesorera del  grupo del Banco Comunal , quien en la foto se encuentra de pie en tercera fila, ocupando el primer lugar de derecha a izquierda, viste una chaqueta de color gris, su cabello es de color castaño claro y lo usa suelto.
Ella se dedica al rubro del comercio específicamente a la venta de ropa usada y nueva, desde hace 5 años. Comenta que trabaja todos los días en diferentes partes como colegios, feria, en su casa y algunas veces se dirige a los domicilios de sus clientelas y su horario lo distribuye de acuerdo a su disponibilidad.
La mercadería en ropa nueva la compra en la ciudad de Santiago a bajo costo por lo tanto conveniente económicamente, y la ropa usada se la regalan amigos y familiares.
Con el crédito comprará ropa de niños, adultos y accesorios como carteras y bolsos.
Una de las metas de Vannesa es instalar un local establecido, ya que de esta manera trabajaría de una forma mas cómoda, evitando el frio durante la temporada de invierno y el calor durante la temporada de verano.
Vannesa vive junto a sus 2 hijos de 13 y 6 años de edad. Sus sueños a nivel laboral sin terminar sus estudios y continuar con el negocio para generar mayores ingresos, así con esto optar a una mejor calidad de vida.
Ella está muy contenta y agradecida de la oportunidad brindada por Fondo Esperanza, ya que le permitirá invertir en su negocio. Comenta que las capacitaciones han sido fundamentales para su negocio y también para su desarrollo personal, ya que ha aprendido a organizar y distribuir de mejor manera sus ingresos e inversiones.
Temuco es la capital de la región de la Araucanía. La ciudad se ubica a 670 kilómetros al sur de Santiago (capital de Chile). En sus alrededores se ubican una serie de balnearios lacustres (Pucón, Villarrica) y una flora y fauna nativa muy llamativas, concentrada en parques naturales cercanos. Cabe destacar que en esta región habita el 50% de los mapuches, pueblo indígena, existente en nuestro país.
texts.en:
This communal bank is called “Tierras Coloradas” (Red Lands) and it has 17 members who are in a variety of lines of work among which are cushion and bath curtain making, used shoe sales, clothes sales, street market merchants, store owners, flower shop, restaurant, crafts and services, among others. All are from the city of Temuco.

Vannesa is communal bank treasurer and in the photo appears standing in the third row, first from right to left wearing a gray jacket.  Her hair is light brown and she wears it lose.

She’s a merchant, specifically selling used and new clothes.  She’s been in business five years.  She comments that she works very day in various places like schools, street markets, at home and sometimes goes house to house visiting her customers.  She arranges her schedule according to availability.  She buys the new clothes in the city of Santiago at low cost which is an economic advantage and the used clothes is given to her by friends and family members.  She will use the loan to buy children’s and adults’ clothes as well as accessories like wallets and purses.  One of Vannesa’s goals is to open a permanent store in order to work more comfortably avoiding the cold in winter and the heat in summer.

Vannesa lives with her two children who are 13 and 6 years of age.  Her dream at a work level is to finish her studies and to continue in business to generate higher income and be able to aspire to a better quality of life this way.

She is very happy and grateful for the opportunity being granted by Fondo Esperanza because it will allow her to invest in her business.  She comments that the training has been fundamental for her business and also for her personal development because she’s learned how to organize and manager her investments and income better.

Temuco is the capital of the Araucanía Region.  The city is located 670 kilometers south of Santiago (Capital of Chile).  There is a series of lakefront resorts around it (Pucón and Villarrica) and very eye-catching native flora and fauna concentrated in nearby nature parks.  It’s worth stressing that 50% of the country’s existing Mapuche (native peoples) population live here.

loans.use: Comprará ropa de niños, adultos y accesorios como carteras y bolsos.

loans.name: Lukia

texts.en: Lukia lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has three children, all of whom go to school. She has no additional family members. She sells second hand clothes at the market. She sells her products on a wholesale and retail basis. She also gets additional income from selling piped water. She has been in this business for the last 10 years. She works six days a week. She has requested a loan of 1,000,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT – SACCO to buy more bales of used clothes. Her major business challenges are transportation and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations are to buy a delivery van to ease in transportation and also educate her children up to university level. She lives in her own house, and the family has access to electricity and piped water.  Her major expenses include paying utility bills and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bales of used clothes

loans.name: Aba

texts.en: Aba is single and has two children. She has received schooling through junior high school. Aba sells banku (fermented maize and cassava dough) in Emissa Krom, near Cape Coast, which she has done for two years. Aba uses her income for paying her children's school fees and other household/living expenses. Aba will use the loan to purchase cassava and maize in bulk. With the new profits from her expanded business, Aba plans to support herself and her family.

loans.use: to purchase cassava and maize in bulk.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah is married and has six children. She sells cosmetics in Emissa Krom, near Cape Coast, which she has done for the past eight years. Her husband is a farmer. Sarah uses her income to pay for her children's school fees. Sarah will use the loan to purchase cosmetics in bulk. With the new profits from her expanded business, Sarah plans to invest in her children's education.

loans.use: to purchase cosmetics in bulk.

loans.name: Abena

texts.en: Abena sells plastic products such as buckets, bowls, and Tupperware in Emissa Krom, near Cape Coast. Abena is single and has three children. Abena has been selling plastic products for the past 2 years. She is responsible for paying school fees as well as all other expenses. Her loan will be used to buy plastic wares in bulk. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to continue to support herself and her children.

loans.use: to buy plastic wares in bulk.

loans.name: Alpha Group

texts.fr: La cliente Nyota, membre du groupe de crédit Alpha, Femme dynamique, entrepreneur, âgée d’environs 30 ans. Elle est vendeuse de braises, farine de manioc. Son mari est un évangéliste intercesseur dans une Eglise locale de réveil. Elle commença ses petits business avec son fonds propre. Plus tard, elle adhéra dans le programme de microcrédit de Hekima pour renforcer ses affaires. Elle vient de réaliser 5 cycles de crédits avec Hekima. Les bénéfices de son activité servent d’épargne, d’alimentation et d’appui à la scolarité de ses enfants. Au cours de la période, cette cliente a vu ses affaires prospèrent positivement. Ainsi elle a décidé d’augmenter son montant de crédit pour ce nouveau cycle. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner avec 3 sacs de braises et 1 sac de farine de manioc. En plus, elle souhaite voir ses enfants grandir et acheter une parcelle dans le futur. La cliente remercie Hekima pour les actions d’autonomisation de pauvres femmes à faible revenu.
texts.en:
This client, Nyota, is a member of the loan group Alpha. She is an energetic woman, an entrepreneur, and about 30 years old, and she sells charcoal and cassava flour. Her husband is an evangelist-intercessor at a local evangelical church. 

She started her small business with her own funds. Later on, she joined the Hekima micro-loan program to bolster her business. She just completed five loan cycles with Hekima. The profits from her business go toward a savings account, food, and covering her children's schooling costs. Over this time, this client saw her business really prosper. So she decided to increase the loan amount for this new cycle.

This new loan will serve to supply her with 3 sacks of charcoal and a sack of cassava flour. In addition, she would like to see her children grow up and to buy a plot of land in the future. 

This client thanks Hekima for its actions helping poor women having low incomes to become autonomous.

loans.use: to buy 3 sacks of charcoal and a sack of cassava flour

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Esi

texts.en: Esi sells salted fish, fruits, and vegetables in Emissa Krom, which is near Cape Coast. Esi is a widow, and all of her children are grown. She has been selling salted fish for four years. She is responsible for taking care of herself and paying for one of her grandchildren's school fees. Her loan will be used to buy fresh fish, fruits, and vegetables in bulk. She hopes to use the new profits to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy fresh fish, fruits, and vegetables in bulk

loans.name: Ama

texts.en: Ama is married and has five children. She operates a provisions store in Emissa Krom, near Cape Coast, which she has done for six years. Her husband is a farmer. Ama uses her income to pay her children’s school fees. Ama will use the loan to purchase foodstuffs and other items for her provisions store. With the new profits from her expanded business, Ama plans to invest in her children's education.

loans.use: to purchase foodstuffs and other items for her provisions store.

loans.name: Gloire A Dieu Group

texts.fr: Le groupe GLOIRE A DIEU est composé de trois personnes qui résident dans un même quartier. C'est la troisième fois que ce groupe sollicite l'aide financier de ALIDé, afin d'élever le niveau de son activité. La représentante du groupe, du nom de Patricia Émilienne est celle qui a la main levée sur la photo. Patricia Émilienne a arrêté l’école au niveau secondaire. Patricia Émilienne est âgée de 43 ans et ne vit plus avec son mari. Le couple a deux enfants, tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Patricia Émilienne vit seule avec ses enfants. Le couple se partage les différentes charges de la maison. Pour contribuer aux différents besoins de la famille, Patricia Émilienne vend divers produits (conserves, pâtes alimentaires et savons) dans son quartier. Cette activité lui permet de répondre sans grande difficulté à ses besoins. Patricia Émilienne s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son chiffre d’affaires et son revenu, Patricia Émilienne sollicite ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe GLOIRE A DIEU, un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Ce prêt leur permettra de rehausser le niveau de leur activité et d’accroître leur clientèle et leur revenu. Les premiers crédits reçus ont été bien remboursés.
texts.en:
The group GLOIRE A DIEU comprises three persons who reside in the same district. This is the third time this group has requested financial aid from ALIDé to boost business. The group's representative, Patricia Émilienne, is the one in the photo with her hand raised. She dropped out of secondary school, is 43 years old, and no longer lives with her husband. The couple have two children, both in school and in their care. Patricia Émilienne lives alone with her children. The couple share in covering the different household expenses.

To help with different family needs, Patricia Émilienne has been selling a variety of goods (canned foods, pasta, soap) in her district. This business enables her to meet her needs without much problem. She gets her supplies from a market in Benin. 

Seeking to satisfy her customers and to grow her sales and revenues, Patricia Émilienne, along with the other members of the group GLOIRE A DIEU, is requesting a third loan from ALIDé. This loan will enable them to raise their level of business and to grow their customer base and their revenues. The previous loans received were indeed paid back.

loans.use: to buy various goods (canned foods, pasta, and soap)

loans.name: Adwowa (Suzzy)

texts.en: Adwowa is married and has three children. She has received no formal education. Adwowa sells second-hand clothing and makes kenkey (fermented maize dough) in Emissa Krom, which is near Cape Coast. She has been doing this for the past two years. Her husband is a farmer. Adwowa uses her income to pay for her children's school fees. Adwowa will use the loan to purchase maize in bulk. In the picture, she is washing maize in preparation for making kenkey. With the new profits, Adwowa plans to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase maize in bulk

loans.name: Efua

texts.en: Efua owns a chop bar (a small restaurant on the side of the road) in Emissa Krom, near Cape Coast. Efua has received no formal education.  She is divorced and has four children. Efua has owned her chop bar for quite a few years now. She is responsible for taking care of her children (feeding/clothing, paying their school fees, etc) as well as taking care of herself. She also pays for other household expenses such as utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy ingredients in bulk for the dishes she makes at her chop bar. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to continue to care for herself and her children.

loans.use: to buy ingredients in bulk for the dishes she makes at her chop bar .

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en: Ekua sells gari and sugar in Emissa Krom, near Cape Coast. Ekua has received schooling through middle school.  She is married and has five children. Her husband is a farmer. Ekua has been selling gari and sugar for eleven years. She is responsible for paying school fees. Her loan will be used to buy gari and sugar in bulk. She hopes to use the new profits to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy gari and sugar in bulk.

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en: Ekua sells towels and washcloths in Emissa Krom, near Cape Coast. She is married and has four children. Her husband is a carpenter. Ekua has been selling towels for some time now. She is responsible for paying school fees. Her loan will be used to buy more towels. She hopes to use the new profits to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more towels.

loans.name: Pin's Group

texts.en: Pin, aged 40, is a married woman living in a rural village of the Prey Chhor District, Kampong Cham province. She has to be responsible for all her four children as they are still in school. For their sake, she and her husband grow paddy rice to make a living. They have engaged in this business for 16 years. For the one cycle that she has been with VisionFund, she has paid back the entire loan already and used it successfully in making good progress with her household and keeping her children in school. Now she leads a group of four members to seek a new loan. She will use her loan portion to buy fertilizer and seed for her farmland. She hopes to earn more income so as to keep her children in school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seed for her farmland

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Prey Chhor district

loans.name: Wiguna Merta Group

texts.en:
To raise capital and increase the number of their pigs, Merta Wiguna group decided to continue borrowing through MUK with eight members and the same loan amount.

Having received support from her husband, Ni Ketut wants to use her loan to buy food and make good cages for piglets. She managed to sell all her piglets in the last period,  and that encouraged Ni Ketut to pursue this venture. She hopes the pigs will not be attacked by disease so she can get maximum results. Profits will be saved for her children's school fees.

loans.use: To buy food and make good cages

loans.name: Pum's Group

texts.en: Pum is the mother of three children, all of whom are still in school. She lives in a rural area in the Dambae district of Kampong Cham province. For the last few years, she has earned a living by growing cassava and now makes about 13,000 KHR per day. She is applying for her second loan from VisionFund.
